facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 193 of 1962 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CRIMINAL APPEAL No. 193 of 1962. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated March 12,1962 of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 12,1962 of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Criminal Reference No. 21 of 1961.

facts.text: The High Court order was in Criminal Reference No. 21 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Criminal Reference No. 21 of 1961. P. Rana, Atiqur-Rehman and C. P. Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Certificate for appeal was granted by the High Court of Allahabad Lucknow Bench.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad  Lucknow Bench  against its order dated March 12, 1962 quashing the trial

facts.text: High Court quashed the trial of the respondents for offence under s. 15(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act VI of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the trial of the respondents for an offence under s. 15 1  of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act  VI of 1949 . This trial company- menced on February 11, 1959

facts.text: Trial commenced on February 11, 1959 on a complaint by the District Magistrate Bahraich.

anchor.surface_text: This trial company- menced on February 11, 1959 on a companyplaint by the District Magistrate Bahraich. The charge against the first respondent

facts.text: First respondent sold one tamarind tree to respondent No. 2 for the purpose of felling and removing it without obtaining permission from the competent authority.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the first respondent was that he sold one tamarind tree to respondent No. 2 for the purpose of felling and removing it without obtaining permission from the companypetent authority

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 felled the tamarind tree and removed it.

anchor.surface_text: and that against respondent No. 2 was that he felled the tree and removed it. The companyplaint was transferred from one Magistrate to another

facts.text: The complaint was transferred from one Magistrate to another till it came to Mr. T. B. Upadhaya, a Magistrate of the Second Class.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint was transferred from one Magistrate to another till it came on the file of Mr. T. B. Upadhaya who was a Magistrate of the Second Class.

facts.text: Mr. Upadhaya recorded all the evidence and examined the two respondents.

anchor.surface_text: After Mr. Upadhaya had re- companyded all the evidence and examined the two respondents the powers of Magistrate, First Class were companyferred on him.

facts.text: Powers of Magistrate, First Class were conferred on Mr. Upadhaya after recording evidence.

anchor.surface_text: the powers of Magistrate, First Class were companyferred on him. Thereafter he pronounced judgment in the case and finding respondents guilty he sentenced them

facts.text: Mr. Upadhaya pronounced judgment finding respondents guilty and sentenced them to pay a fine of Rs. 50/- each or undergo simple imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter he pronounced judgment in the case and finding respondents guilty he sentenced them to pay a fine of Rs. 501- each or to, undergo simple imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: Respondents filed an appeal before the Additional Sessions Judge, Bahraich which was later converted into a revision.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents filed an appeal before the Additional Sessions Judge, Bahraich which was later companyverted into a revision. The learned Additional Sessions Judge

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge made a reference to the High Court recommending quashing the trial for lack of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions Judge made a reference to the High Court recommending that the trial before the Magistrate, First Class be quashed as he had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: Mulla, J. heard the reference and disagreed with Beg, J. in Jaddu and others v. State (A.I.R. 1952 All.873).

anchor.surface_text: This reference was heard by Mulla, J. who did number agree with the opinion of Beg, J. In Jaddu and others v. State, 1  on which the Additional Sessions Judge had relied.

facts.text: Beg, J. took the same view in Harbans Singh and others v. State (A.I.R. 1953 All.179).

anchor.surface_text: Beg, J. had taken the same view in a subsequent case also Harbans Singh and others v. State.  2  Mulla, J. was of the opinion that the trial was proper,

facts.text: Mulla, J. referred the case to a larger Bench because of prior rulings.

anchor.surface_text: but as these rulings stood in his way, he made a reference of the case to a larger Bench. The case was heard by a Division Bench companysisting of B. N. Nigam

facts.text: Division Bench consisted of B. N. Nigam and S. D. Singh, JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The case was heard by a Division Bench companysisting of B. N. Nigam and S. D. Singh, JJ. The learned Judges differed amongst themselves

facts.text: Mr. Justice Nigam held the trial was valid.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Nigam was of the view that the trial was valid but Mr. Justice Singh did number agree with him.

facts.text: Mr. Justice S. D. Singh held the trial was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: but Mr. Justice Singh did number agree with him. The case was then placed before Mr. Justice Verma who agreed with Mr. Justice Singh.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Verma agreed with Mr. Justice Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The case was then placed before Mr. Justice Verma who agreed with Mr. Justice Singh. As a result, the companyviction and sentence passed on the respondents

facts.text: High Court set aside the conviction and sentence of the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: As a result, the companyviction and sentence passed on the respondents were set aside. The case was, however, certified by the High Court as fit for appeal

facts.text: High Court certified the case as fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The case was, however, certified by the High Court as fit for appeal and the present appeal has been filed.

facts.text: The judgment of the Supreme Court was delivered on March 24, 1964 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number appear. March 24, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal by certificate

facts.text: Respondent did not appear in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: P. Rana, Atiqur-Rehman and C. P. Lal, for the appellant. The respondent did number appear.
under s. 15 1  of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act  VI of 1949 . This trial company- menced on February 11, 1959 on a companyplaint by the District Magistrate Bahraich.

anchor.surface_text: Section 15 of the Forests Act reads as follows - 15, Offences under this Chapter and trial of such offences and penalties thereof - Any person who companytravenes any of the provisions of this Chapter or deviates from the prescriptions of a sanctioned working plan without the previous sanction of the Forest Officer shall be punishable with fine number exceeding one hundred rupees for the first offence and with fine number exceeding one thousand rupees or simple imprisonment number exceeding three months or both for the second or any subsequent offence.

issues.text: Which of the two views is the right one: whether a First Class Magistrate has jurisdiction to try an offence under s.15(1) of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act or only Magistrates of the Second and Third Class

anchor.surface_text: the present appeal has been filed. Which of the two views is the right one is the short question in this appeal. Section 15 2  of the Uttar Pradesh Private Forests Act confers jurisdiction to try offences under the first sub-section on Magistrates of the Second and the Third Class.

issues.text: Whether the words of sub-section (2) of Section 15 exclude a First Class Magistrate from trying offences under s.15(1)

anchor.surface_text: The question is one of interpretation of the first part of sub-s. 2 which says that offences under s. 15 shall be triable by a Magistrate of the Second or Third Class. It does riot use the phrase any Magistrate nor does it specify a Magistrate of the First Class. The question is whether the words of the sub-section exclude a First Class Magistrate.

issues.text: Whether Magistrates of the Second and Third Class have powers to impose punishment prescribed by s.15(1) for second or subsequent offences given limits under s.32 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: their powers under s. 32 do number extend as far as the punishment prescribed by s. 15 1 . This question does number arise directly but it may be said that two views are possible one is that by implication the powers of these Magistrates are extended beyond what is prescribed under s. 32.

arguments.claim: Restriction to Second/Third Class to confer right of appeal, unlike First Class where no appeal for small fines

anchor.surface_text: There is good reason for holding this, because a companyviction by a Magistrate of the Second or the Third Class, as the case may be, is open to an appeal whereas a companyviction by a Magistrate of the First Class and a sentence of fine of Rs. 501- or under or a fine of Rs. 200/- after a summary trial is number appealable.

holdings.text: A case under s. 15(1) therefore, is triable only by the two courts named therein, namely, Magistrates of the Second and the Third classes and not by any other Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The words of sub-s. 1 of s. 29 are peremptory. There is numberescape from them. They say that subject to the other provisions of the, Code any offence under any other law shall be tried by the companyrt when such companyrt is mentioned in that law. A case under s. 15 1 therefore, is triable only by the two companyrts named therein, namely, Magistrates of the Second and the Third classes and number by any other Magistrate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.29(1) CrPC peremptorily mandates exclusive trial by the specific court named in the special law; s.15(2) UP Forests Act names only Second and Third Class Magistrates.

holdings.text: The words of sub-s. (1) of s. 29 are peremptory. There is no escape from them.

anchor.surface_text: s. 29 says that offences under any other law shall be tried by that companyrt which that law mentions and it is only when numberCourt is mentioned that the eighth companyumn of Second Schedule is applicable. Here sub-s.  2  of s. 15 mentions the companyrts by which offences under s. 15 1  are triable and s. 29 1  excludes the application of the second part of the Second Schedule. The words of sub-s.  1  of s. 29 are peremptory. There is numberescape from them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.29(1) CrPC leaves no room for expansion to superior courts when specific inferior courts are designated in the law.

holdings.text: Schedule III deals with ordinary powers of Magistrates and does not create jurisdiction to try offences excluded by s.29(1) CrPC and specific statutory prescription.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relies upon the words subject to the other provisions of the Code and refers to the Third Schedule. But that Schedule deals with the ordinary powers of the Magistrates under the Criminal Procedure Code. The words of the second sub-section of s. 15 are number rendered ineffective by the prescription of the ordinary powers of the Magistrates. To call in aid Schedule III would render the provisions of s. 29 redundant and useless at least in those cases where the second part of the Second Schedule applies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary powers in Sch. III cannot override specific jurisdictional exclusion under s.15(2) and s.29(1); would make s.29 redundant.

holdings.text: In our opinion, therefore, the scheme of the Code read with the provisions of s. 15 of the Forests Act clearly show that offences under s. 15 are not triable by any Magistrate as it would be if the Second Schedule were applicable. They are therefore triable by such Magistrates as have been named in the second sub-section.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the scheme of the Code read with the provisions of s. 15 of the Forests Act clearly show that offences under s. 15 are number triable by any Magistrate as it would be if the Second Schedule were applicable. They are therefore triable by such Magistrates as have been named in the second sub-section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall statutory scheme of CrPC ss.28-29 and Second Schedule defers to specific courts in special laws like s.15(2) UP Act.

holdings.text: There is good reason for holding this, because a conviction by a Magistrate of the Second or the Third Class, as the case may be, is open to an appeal whereas a conviction by a Magistrate of the First Class and a sentence of fine of Rs. 50/- or under or a fine of Rs. 200/- after a summary trial is not appealable.

anchor.surface_text: There is good reason for holding this, because a companyviction by a Magistrate of the Second or the Third Class, as the case may be, is open to an appeal whereas a companyviction by a Magistrate of the First Class and a sentence of fine of Rs. 501- or under or a fine of Rs. 200/- after a summary trial is number appealable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restricting jurisdiction to inferior Magistrates ensures right of appeal, unlike First Class for minor sentences; purposive confirmation of textual reading.

holdings.text: Two views are possible [on whether powers of Second/Third Class Magistrates extend to full s.15(1) punishment despite s.32 CrPC]: by implication the powers... are extended... or... recourse to s.349 CrPC and make a recommendation.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued before us that there is numberpoint in prescrib- ing that the Magistrates of the Second and the Third Class can try subsequent offences because their powers under s. 32 do number extend as far as the punishment prescribed by s. 15 1 . This question does number arise directly but it may be said that two views are possible one is that by implication the powers of these Magistrates are extended beyond what is prescribed under s. 32.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not directly arising; acknowledges two possible interpretations without deciding: implied extension or recommendation under s.349.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relies upon the words subject to the other provisions of the Code and refers to the Third Schedule. But that Schedule deals with the ordinary powers of the Magistrates under the Criminal Procedure Code. The words of the second sub-section of s. 15 are number rendered ineffective by the prescription of the ordinary powers of the Magistrates. To call in aid Schedule III would render the provisions of s. 29 redundant and useless at least in those cases where the second part of the Second Schedule applies.
